summary: Kahneman's Two Selves framework (Part V of Thinking, Fast and Slow) reveals that the guest's rebooking decision is governed not by the totality of their lived experience during the lease, but by the remembering self's distorted summary -- the peak moment and the ending. These seven UI elements architect the two most consequential moments in the guest journey (move-in peak and lease-end finale) alongside the search, negotiation, milestone, and dashboard surfaces that manufacture, protect, and retain the memories that drive retention. The peak-end rule means move-in and lease-end together have more power over rebooking than everything between them combined. Duration neglect means a 16-week lease is remembered no differently than a 4-week lease unless the platform engineers memorable peaks at strategic intervals. The focusing illusion means whatever the guest attends to first at any moment defines their evaluation. Every UI element in this set is designed to direct attention, manufacture peaks, and architect endings.

elements.name: Move-In Welcome Peak Card
elements.description: A full-screen welcome card that appears as the guest's first interaction after check-in, engineering a positive peak through a cinematic four-frame reveal: hero photo, host welcome message, neighborhood essentials, and a first-impression sentiment capture. Kahneman's peak-end rule establishes that this moment will disproportionately define the guest's memory of the entire lease. The card commands the full viewport to direct the focusing illusion exclusively toward warmth and preparation. The host's personal message creates the human peak the remembering self stores; the neighborhood essentials answer 'now what?' before anxiety forms. Value before the ask: three frames of welcome precede the single gentle prompt.

visual_spec.layout: Full viewport takeover on first open after check-in. Hero photo fills 100% width, 60vh height. Content card overlays bottom 50% with 24px padding. After dismissal, persists as a standard 100%-width dashboard card for 48 hours.
visual_spec.background: Hero photo full-bleed; content overlay uses var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) with backdrop-filter blur(12px)
visual_spec.border: none on takeover; 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb) on dashboard card state
visual_spec.border_radius: 0 on takeover; 12px on dashboard card state

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Triggers on first app/dashboard open after check-in time. Hero photo fades in over 500ms ease-in. Content card slides up from bottom over 400ms ease-out, 300ms after photo starts. Essentials stagger in 100ms apart. Dismissable by scroll-past or 'Done' tap.
interaction_spec.hover: Sentiment options scale to 1.05 on hover with 100ms ease-out. Selected option fills with its color and shows a checkmark.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All elements appear simultaneously without animation. Card appears as standard dashboard card (no takeover).

copy_spec.host_message_example: Sarah left a note: 'The rooftop has the best sunset view in the building -- take the stairs at the end of the hall. Enjoy!'
dont: Lead with rules or house manual content
Use generic 'Welcome to Split Lease!' language
Show issue-reporting in the first 3 frames
Include administrative items (payment, lease terms)

elements.html_css:
Welcome to Williamsburg

Sarah prepared this for you

The rooftop has the best sunset view in the building -- take the stairs at the end of the hall. The morning light in the living room is beautiful. Enjoy!

Your essentials nearby

Blue Bottle Coffee

3 min walk

Whole Foods Market

5 min walk

Bedford Ave (L train)

2 min walk

How does the space feel?
elements.problem_it_solves: Move-in is the single most consequential moment in the guest journey, yet it receives no deliberate design. The welcome peak card engineers a positive first impression that the remembering self stores as the lease's defining memory, using the focusing illusion to direct attention toward warmth (host message, neighborhood orientation) before any negative detail is noticed.

elements.name: Lease-End Farewell Ceremony Card
elements.description: A three-state evolving card that creates a graduated positive ending over the final 7 days of a lease. State 1 (Reflection) shows the lease summary and invites a memory prompt. State 2 (Farewell) adds the host's closing message and re-surfaces the neighborhood essentials from move-in as a narrative bookend. State 3 (Gratitude) presents the complete lease narrative with a rebooking prompt positioned at peak emotional warmth. Kahneman's cold-hand experiment showed that 80% of subjects chose to repeat experiences with gradually improving endings -- this card creates that gradient: neutral reflection to warm farewell to peak gratitude.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width dashboard card. Three evolving states share the same card shell (no page navigation). State 3 includes a hero photo element at top. Max-width 520px centered.

typography.phase_label: var(--font-inter), 11px, weight 600, var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109,49,194)), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.5px
typography.headline: var(--font-dm), 20px, weight 700, var(--primary-purple, #31135D)

interaction_spec.load_behavior: State 1 slides in on dashboard 7 days before final stay (300ms ease-out). State 2 evolves in place when host message arrives (message slides in 300ms ease-out). State 3 cross-fades from State 2 (400ms ease-in-out) 24 hours after final departure.
interaction_spec.hover: Rebook CTA shows subtle scale (0.97 to 1.0) on click. Memory prompt textarea has focus ring matching purple palette.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All state transitions are instant. No slide or cross-fade.

copy_spec.memory_prompt: What will you remember most about this space?
copy_spec.state2_host_message_example: It was wonderful having you -- the apartment felt alive when you were here. Come back anytime.
dont: Lead with administrative items (deposit, invoice)
Use urgency language for rebooking
Show the review prompt as the primary element
Frame the ending as a loss ('Access deactivated')

elements.html_css:
12 stays completed

Your lease is complete

Three months in Williamsburg

Mar 15 - Jun 15
Hosted by Sarah
12 stays

Sarah left you a note

It was wonderful having you -- the apartment felt alive when you were here. Come back anytime.

Your spots in Williamsburg

Blue Bottle Coffee, 3 min
Whole Foods, 5 min
elements.problem_it_solves: The platform has no designed lease ending. The guest's final interaction is administrative (deposit, checkout), producing a flat memory that does not motivate rebooking. This card creates the gradually improving ending that Kahneman's research shows produces a preference for repetition: 80% of subjects chose to repeat experiences with gradually improving endings.

elements.name: Peak-Generating Listing Card
elements.description: A richly layered listing card that maximizes peak probability per impression by providing multiple visual peak opportunities. The photo carousel auto-advances on hover, the neighborhood identity pill creates an experiential memory anchor, and the availability alignment signal resolves the fundamental question without a page transition. Kahneman Ch 35: the search session will be prototyped by one card impression. Every enrichment layer multiplies the probability that this card's impression is vivid and positive. The focusing illusion is directed toward experiential qualities (neighborhood, transit) rather than transactional ones (price) to produce richer memories that support rebooking.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, 300px width on desktop grid. Hero photo area at full bleed top (aspect 3:2). Content area below with 12px padding. Hover reveals additional layers.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Cards fade in from opacity 0 to 1 over 200ms ease-out as they enter viewport. Staggered 50ms per card. Photo carousel shows first image with dots and image counter badge.
interaction_spec.hover: Card lifts translateY(-2px) with shadow upgrade over 200ms ease-in-out. Carousel auto-advances 2.5s interval with 250ms crossfade on 800ms hover delay. Image counter updates. Neighborhood pill and availability signal become visible. Save heart appears top-right. Hover drawer slides up from bottom with transit info and Message Host button.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: No transform, no auto-advance. Card gains 2px solid var(--secondary-purple) border on hover instead. All hover-reveal elements appear instantly.

dont: Make price the largest/first text element
Show full address on the card
Use 'View listing' as primary CTA
Add lease terms or long descriptions

elements.html_css:
1/5
Williamsburg
$175/night
Available your dates
3 min to L train
elements.problem_it_solves: The search session will be remembered by one prototypical listing card. A card with only a photo and price provides one peak opportunity. This card provides six: photo carousel, neighborhood identity, transit proximity, availability alignment, save action, and message action. Each enrichment multiplies the probability that the search memory is vivid and positive.

elements.name: Mid-Lease Narrative Milestone Card
elements.description: A lightweight narrative card that appears at strategic intervals during the active lease to combat duration neglect. Kahneman Ch 35: 'duration had no effect whatsoever on the ratings.' Without designed mid-lease peaks, weeks 2-15 of a 16-week lease are mnemonically invisible. This card creates temporal anchors that the remembering self can store: 'Halfway through. What has been the best part?' The milestone treatment uses controlled visual emphasis (DM Sans headline, off-white background, purple accent border) to distinguish it from routine stay cards while preserving the dashboard's operational order.

visual_spec.layout: Standard dashboard card width, 100% of content area. Slightly elevated visual treatment to distinguish from operational cards.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb); left border: 3px solid var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109,49,194))

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card slides in on dashboard at lease midpoint (300ms ease-out). Persists for 72 hours, then dims to 60% opacity and moves to 'Past moments' section.
interaction_spec.hover: Quick-tap options darken background on hover. Selected option shows purple border and subtle fill. Text field expandable on focus.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Card appears instantly without slide. All transitions instant.

copy_spec.headline: Halfway through
copy_spec.prompt: What has been the best part so far?
copy_spec.acknowledgment: Glad to hear it. [X] stays to go.
dont: Use survey language ('Rate 1-5')
Create urgency or obligation
Upsell longer leases or other listings
Show more than one milestone card at a time

elements.html_css:
Halfway through

6 of 12 stays in Williamsburg

What has been the best part so far?
elements.problem_it_solves: Duration neglect makes the middle weeks of a lease mnemonically invisible. The remembering self discards weeks 2-15 of a 16-week lease because nothing stands out. This card creates temporal anchors -- moments of positive reflection that break the adaptation monotony and give the remembering self data points beyond just the peak and end.

elements.name: Counter-Offer Common-Ground Card
elements.description: A counter-proposal view that leads with the host's personal message and common ground before revealing changed terms, directly combating Kahneman's loss aversion. The staggered rendering order (host message at 200ms, common ground at 400ms, changes at 600ms) ensures the guest processes human warmth and agreement before encountering any parameter changes. No red, no strikethrough, no 'rejected' language. The action labels use the host's name and collaborative framing: 'Accept Sarah's suggestion' instead of 'Accept counter-proposal.' The remembering self stores the negotiation as defined by its peak moment -- this design ensures that peak is the host's warm message, not the shock of changed numbers.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width card. Host message section at top, common ground section with colored background, changes section in neutral, action bar at bottom. Max-width 520px.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Host message fades in at 200ms. Common ground section slides in from left at 400ms ease-out. Changes section follows at 600ms. Action bar appears at 800ms. Staggered rendering creates a reading rhythm: warmth > agreement > detail > action.
interaction_spec.hover: Accept button shows scale pulse 0.97 on click. Adjust Terms button shows purple border highlight. Message link underlines on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All sections appear simultaneously without animation.

dont: Use 'Counter-proposal received' language
Highlight changes in red or strikethrough
Create urgency ('Respond within 48 hours')
Omit the host's personal message

elements.html_css:
Sarah responded to your proposal

Sarah would love to have you

I'd love to have you! 10 weeks works better for my schedule because I have family visiting in May. Everything else looks perfect -- can't wait to welcome you.

Where you agree

Tue - Thu schedule$180/nightStarting March 1

Sarah suggested a change

Your proposal

16 weeks

Sarah's suggestion

10 weeks
elements.problem_it_solves: Loss aversion turns counter-proposals into rejection experiences. The guest processes the loss (6 fewer weeks) more intensely than the gain (securing the stay). This card redirects the focusing illusion from loss to relationship by leading with human warmth and agreement, producing a 'we worked it out' memory instead of a 'they rejected me' memory.

elements.name: Lease Summary Memory Card
elements.description: A compact narrative artifact displayed on the active lease dashboard that shows the guest's lease story in progress -- stays completed, host name, neighborhood, and the guest's own milestone reflection. This card serves the remembering self by providing a visual summary that accumulates over the lease, combating duration neglect by making the passage of time visible and meaningful. At lease end, this card's data feeds into the Farewell Ceremony Card, creating narrative continuity from the middle to the ending. The card uses the precision register (Inter with tabular numbers) for factual data and the narrative register (DM Sans) for the headline, creating a visual artifact that feels like a personal record of the experience.

visual_spec.layout: Standard dashboard card width, compact height. Summary stats in a horizontal row, guest reflection below if available. Max-width 440px.

typography.headline: var(--font-dm), 15px, weight 700, var(--primary-purple, #31135D)
typography.reflection_text: var(--font-inter), 13px, weight 400, color: var(--text-description, #374151), font-style: italic

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card appears on dashboard after the first completed stay. Stats update after each stay completion with a brief number roll animation (200ms). Progress bar fills incrementally.
interaction_spec.hover: Card does not have interactive hover states. It is a passive narrative artifact.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Number updates are instant. Progress bar fills without animation.

copy_spec.headline: Your stay in [neighborhood]
copy_spec.reflection_label: You said the best part was:
copy_spec.no_reflection: No reflection is shown if the guest has not yet completed the mid-lease check-in
dont: Show payment or financial data
Include issue history or complaints
Add gamified badges or achievement language
Use this card as a review prompt

elements.html_css:
Your stay in Williamsburg

8stays
10weeks
Sarahyour host
You said the best part was:

"The neighborhood -- everything I need is a short walk away."
elements.problem_it_solves: During the active lease, the experiencing self adapts and the remembering self has nothing to store. The Lease Summary Memory Card makes the passage of time visible and meaningful by accumulating narrative data (stays, weeks, host name, reflection) that the remembering self can reference. At lease end, this accumulated narrative feeds into the farewell sequence, creating a through-line from middle to ending that combats duration neglect.

elements.name: Guest Stay Dashboard with Experiential Data
elements.description: The primary active-lease dashboard view that serves both the experiencing self (daily operations) and the remembering self (narrative peaks). The dashboard has two visual registers: an operational zone (upcoming stay, date tools, payment status) in clean, neutral styling, and a narrative zone (milestone card, lease summary, host connection prompt) in the warm purple-accented treatment. The experiencing self finds reliability; the remembering self finds memorable moments. Kahneman Ch 37: 'happiness is the experience of spending time with people you love' -- the platform should not try to be the source of happiness during the lease; it should remove obstacles to the guest's own happiness while strategically manufacturing peaks for the remembering self.

visual_spec.layout: Single-column dashboard, max-width 600px centered. Operational zone at top (hero card pattern), narrative zone below (when active). Lease Summary Memory Card embedded in the narrative zone.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-light, #f9fafb) for page; var(--bg-white, #ffffff) for operational cards; var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) for narrative cards

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Operational zone loads first (hero stay card appears in 150ms). Narrative zone loads below if a narrative card is active (300ms ease-out slide-in). Baseline transitions between stay states are near-invisible (150ms).
interaction_spec.hover: Operational cards have minimal hover states (subtle border color shift). Narrative cards have warm hover states (shadow deepens slightly). Action buttons within cards follow standard purple button interaction (scale 0.97 on click).
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All elements appear instantly. No slide-ins or transitions.

copy_spec.baseline_notification: Your next stay starts Tuesday, Mar 24.
dont: Over-notify for routine events
Mix narrative and operational elements in the same card
Use excitement language for routine operations
Show more than one narrative card at a time in the narrative zone

elements.html_css:

Tue, Mar 17 - Thu, Mar 19

All clear · Cleaning photos received

Your journey

You've been staying with Sarah for 8 weeks

Your halfway check-in is coming up. Take a moment to reflect on how things are going.
elements.problem_it_solves: The active lease dashboard currently serves only the experiencing self (operational data: stays, dates, cleaning). The remembering self finds nothing memorable in weekly operational cards. This dashboard adds a narrative zone that manufactures strategic peaks (milestones, host connections, reflections) within the stable operational structure -- serving both selves simultaneously and ensuring the lease middle produces memories, not just operations.
